register/style
Большая Никитская

This historical street in central Moscow connects the Garden Ring to Mokhovaya Street. The old Moscow State University and Conservatory were located here. Alexander Pushkin married Natalia Goncharova at the Greater Church of the Ascension found on this street.

Улица в центре Москвы. Изображено ниже:

location Russia
Типографiя

As Sokolov moves into this extended parody of nineteenth-century literature, he retains the pre-reform orthography of the book’s publisher. Alexey Salomatin and Artem Skvortsov have argued that “working with the matrices present in his contemporary culture, Sokolov is not parodical [пародиен], but parodic [пародичен] […] He does not seek to satirically discredit this or that reproduced manner — his task is fundamentally different: to show the most aesthetically productive potencies of someone else’s writing and include them in his artistic system” (345).

Верный своей затянутой пародии на литературу XIX века, Соколов придерживается дореформенной орфографии в названии типографии книги.

language
Типографiя товарищества И. Н. Кушнерова и Ко

This typography did really exist, as it is recounted here: “In January 1876, he [Ivan Kushnerev] founded the ‘Kushnerev I. N. & Co’ publishing house that began printing its own and custom publications of excellent typographic quality intrinsic to the publishing house. In 1891, the works of Mikhail Lermontov were published in three volumes, illustrated by the 14 greatest Russian artists M. Vrubel, K. Korovin, I. Repin, et al. This edition was the first one to include M. Vrubel’s illustrations to ‘Demon.’ A series of popular brochures ‘War and Culture’ attained great fame. Kushnerev became known as a philanthropist who generously donated to charity in Moscow. In 1883–84 he actively participated in creating a special Graphic group of typography and lithography artists under the Moscow Office of the Imperial Russian Technical Society. The association published around 60 books in total. In 1918, the association was nationalized, and the publishing house was renamed to ‘Red Proletarian’ in 1922. The Pimenovskaya street, where the enterprises of Kushenerev were situated, was renamed to Krasnoproletarskaya (Red Proletarian) after the publishing house in 1929.”

Эта типография действительно существовала, как описано здесь: “В январе 1876 основал издательство на вере «Кушнерев И. Н. и Ко», начавшее выпускать на свойственной его типографии высоком полиграфическом уровне собственные и заказные издания. В 1891 году были выпущены сочинения Михаила Лермонтова в 3-х томах, с рисунками 14-ти крупнейших русских художников М. Врубеля, К. Коровина, И. Репина, В. Серова и др. В этом издании впервые были опубликованы — рисунки М. Врубеля к «Демону». Большую известность получила серия популярных брошюр «Война и Культура». Кушнерев прославился как меценат, дававший большие средства на благотворительные цели в Москве. В 1883—84 годах он принял активное участие в создании при Московском отделении императорского Русского технического общества особой Графической группы из типографов и литографов. Всего товарищество издало около 60-ти названий книг. В 1918 году товарищество было национализировано, а типография с 1922 года стала называться «Красный пролетарий». В 1929 году Пименовская улица, на которой долгое время располагались предприятия Кушнерева, в честь типографии была переименована в Краснопролетарскую.”

explanatory
со двора, во дворе

Starting from this repetition on (“so dvora” - “vo dvore”) the chapter welcomes a long digression that takes the reader back in time to the end of 19th century - beginning of the 20th century and makes him acquainted with Yakov’s great-grandfather.

Начиная с этого повтора (“со двора” - “во дворе”), глава плавно переходит к продолжительному отступлению, которое уносит читателя назад во времени к концу XIX века - началу XX века и знакомит его с прадедом Якова.

register/style
дюймовым

Interestingly, the narrator chooses inches as unit of length. This small nuance is a detail of Sokolov’s extended parody of the 19th century literature: the metric system was implemented in Soviet Russia only after 1918. The obsolete Russian units of measurement were redefined to match the English system through an imperial decree in 1835, which explains the author’s use of inches here. The inch (as well as the foot) were introduced in Russia by Peter the Great at the beginning of the 18th century.

Любопытно, но автор здесь выбирает дюймы как единицу измерения длины. Этот небольшой нюанс — деталь затянутой пародии Соколова на литературу XIX века: метрическая система была введена в Советской России только после 1918 года. Русская система мер была стандартизирована на основе английских мер императорским указом 1835 года, чем и объясняется авторское использование здесь дюймов. Дюймы (как и футы) были представлены в России Петром Великим в начале XVIII века.

register/style Russia archaism
суглинистой жижи

Loam soil, in this case watery, liquid.

Суглинистая почва, в данном случае, полужидкая.

разор

register/style
на всю Елоховскую бранит

Ostanin (43) interprets this as a variation of the set expressions “krichat’ vo vsyu ivanovskuyu” (to shout loudly) or “zvonit’ vo vsyu ivanovskuyu” (to go or do something very fast and/or as hard as possible). On Ivanovskaya square, which is located inside the Kremlin, the Tsar’s decrees were read out. In Sokolov’s text, however, we read “Elokhovskaya”: Elokhovskaya church (and relative square) is located between the Kazansky and Yaroslavsky stations and Lefortovsky park in Moscow. It was here that the poet A.S. Pushkin was baptised in 1799. Back in 1469 the yurodivyi Vasily (the holy fool to which Saint Basil’s Cathedral on the Red Square is dedicated) was also born here. The church is

Останин (43) трактует это как вариацию выражение “кричит во всю ивановскую” (громко кричать) или “звонит во всю ивановскую” (делать что-то изо всех сил). На Ивановской площади в Кремле оглашались царские указы. В тексте Соколова, однако, читается “Елоховская”: Елоховская церковь (и соответствующая площадь) расположена между Казанским и Ярославским вокзалом и Лефортовским парком в Москве. Здесь был крещен поэт А.С. Пушкин в 1799 году. Здесь также был рожден в 1469 году юродивый Василий, в честь которого назван Храм Василия Блаженного на Красной площади. Церковь изображена ниже:

метранпаж

From the French “metteur en pages”: typesetter, collating the typeset material and making final preparations for print.

С французского “metteur en pages”: специалист вёрстки, который разбивает текст на отдельные страницы и подготавливает оригинал-макет издания.

foreign explanatory
Никодим

Nicodemus is a Biblical name. According to John’s Gospel, he is described as a learned doctor of the Law, a Pharisee, a member of the Sanhedrin, and one of Jesus’ disciples. An apocryphal Gospel is attributed to him by tradition.

Никодим — библейское имя. Согласно Евангелию от Иоанна, образованный законоучитель, фарисей, член синедриона и один из учеников Иисуса. По традиции, ему присваивается одно из апокрифических евангелий.

character bible intertextuality religion
Ермолаич

Patronymic, son of Ermolai. Ermolai is a name of Greek origin, meaning approximately “people of Hermes”, herald of the gods and god of commerce.

Отчество: сын Ермолая. Ермолай — имя греческого происхождения, примерно означающее “люди Гермеса”, посланника богов и бога торговли.

character explanatory
Паламахтеров

Ostanin suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of “Palamakherov” (from the verb palit’, to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires (43). On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are “So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!” (“Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки”) (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию “Паломахеров” (от глагола “палить”), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: “Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки” (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).

intratextuality intertextuality character
прадед

So Nikodim may be the grandfather of Ilya.

Предполагается, что Никодим может быть дедом Ильи.

character explanatory
Якова

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильича

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

register/style
Кушнерова

This typography did really exist, as it is recounted here: “In January 1876, he [Ivan Kushnerev] founded the ‘Kushnerev I. N. & Co’ publishing house that began printing its own and custom publications of excellent typographic quality intrinsic to the publishing house. In 1891, the works of Mikhail Lermontov were published in three volumes, illustrated by the 14 greatest Russian artists M. Vrubel, K. Korovin, I. Repin, et al. This edition was the first one to include M. Vrubel’s illustrations to ‘Demon.’ A series of popular brochures ‘War and Culture’ attained great fame. Kushnerev became known as a philanthropist who generously donated to charity in Moscow. In 1883–84 he actively participated in creating a special Graphic group of typography and lithography artists under the Moscow Office of the Imperial Russian Technical Society. The association published around 60 books in total. In 1918, the association was nationalized, and the publishing house was renamed to ‘Red Proletarian’ in 1922. The Pimenovskaya street, where the enterprises of Kushenerev were situated, was renamed to Krasnoproletarskaya (Red Proletarian) after the publishing house in 1929.”

Эта типография действительно существовала, как описано здесь: “В январе 1876 основал издательство на вере «Кушнерев И. Н. и Ко», начавшее выпускать на свойственной его типографии высоком полиграфическом уровне собственные и заказные издания. В 1891 году были выпущены сочинения Михаила Лермонтова в 3-х томах, с рисунками 14-ти крупнейших русских художников М. Врубеля, К. Коровина, И. Репина, В. Серова и др. В этом издании впервые были опубликованы — рисунки М. Врубеля к «Демону». Большую известность получила серия популярных брошюр «Война и Культура». Кушнерев прославился как меценат, дававший большие средства на благотворительные цели в Москве. В 1883—84 годах он принял активное участие в создании при Московском отделении императорского Русского технического общества особой Графической группы из типографов и литографов. Всего товарищество издало около 60-ти названий книг. В 1918 году товарищество было национализировано, а типография с 1922 года стала называться «Красный пролетарий». В 1929 году Пименовская улица, на которой долгое время располагались предприятия Кушнерева, в честь типографии была переименована в Краснопролетарскую.”

register/style
новоявленном аппарате мусье Люмьера

Cinema. The Lumière brothers, Auguste Marie Louis Nicolas Lumière (19 October 1862 – 10 April 1954) and Louis Jean Lumière (5 October 1864 – 6 June 1948), were French manufacturers of photography equipment and filmmakers. They are best known for the invention of the cinématographe, a three-in-one device that could record, develop, and project motion pictures. The original cinématographe had been patented by Léon Guillaume Bouly on 12 February 1892, and the device was further developed by the Lumières, who patented their own version on 13 February 1895. The Lumières went on to produce short films between 1895 and 1905, and they may have organized the very first presentation of projected film. Audiences, it turned out, preferred projected films, which could be viewed by many people at once, to “peepshow” devices like Thomas Edison’s kinetoscope, which only allowed one viewer at a time. Here, “Monsieur Lumière” may refer exclusively to Louis Lumière, who was more involved in the invention of the cinématographe than his brother.

Кинематограф.

Останин замечает ахронизм: братья Люмьер запатентовали кинематограф в 1895 году, тогда как книга Каруса Штерна была издана на русском языке 20 лет спустя (Ostanin 44).

foreign explanatory
сапогах

Boots with high tops. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Литературный, поэтический или иронический: двигаться (пешком), идти чинно, важно.

register/style
встреч

Although at first look a misspelling, Sokolov affirms “it is not a typo, but a synonym for ‘navstrechu’, a synonym that is not used today, it has become very archaic, I have not found it in dictionaries, but in the past I found it in texts of past centuries, I think it is not my invention” (personal communication, June 27 2023).

Хотя с первого взгляда выглядит как опечатка, Соколов объясняет, что “встреч - не опечатка, а синоним слова навстречу, синоним, который теперь не используется, он стал очень архаичным, я не нашел его в словарях, но прежде встречал в текстах прошлых веков, думаю, он не является моим изобретением” (личная переписка, 27 июня 2023).

language archaism
какими судьбами

Set expression: how did you end up here?

Устойчивое выражение: (при неожиданной встрече) как вы здесь оказались?

Соколов комментирует: “Не знаю, как теперь, но в прошлом и позапрошлом веках стулья, сработанные в Вене, на каких-то там фабриках, считались моднейшими и лучшими в мире” (личная переписка, 27 июня 2023).

register/style
ассигнацiями

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme “i” was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: ассигнациями). The assignation ruble was the first paper currency to appear in the Russian Empire (1769).

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема “i” была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы “ассигнациями”). Ассигнационный рубль был первой бумажной валютой, появившейся в Российской империи (1769).

жокейском

A jockey is a rider in horse race.

Профессиональный наездник на скачках.

explanatory
гипподрома

From the Greek ἱππόδρομος (ἵππος, “horse” and δρόμος, “course”) — a stadium for horse and chariot racing. Now used to refer to a horse track. Here, Nikodim refers to the Central Moscow Hippodrome, which was founded in 1834. Ilya also refers to this hippodrome in chapter 6 (R193/E78).

С греческого ἱππόδρομος (ἵππος, “лошадь” и δρόμος, “бег, площадь для состязаний в беге”) — архитектурное сооружение для конных скачек и гонок колесниц. Сейчас относится к конно-спортивному комплексу. Здесь, Никодим имеет в виду Центральный московский ипподром, основанный в 1834. Изображено ниже:

Илья упоминает тот же ипподром в главе 6 (R193/E78).

оне самыя

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: today would be они самые. In previous editions of the book, here we read a regular “они самые.”

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное написание было бы “они самые”. Стоит отметить, что в предыдущих изданиях романа в этом месте было сохранено современное написание.

phraseologism
пахитосками

Slim cigarettes. According to Dal’ dictionary, these cigarettes came from Spain and were made out of corn leaves (Ostanin 45).

Папиросы, тонкие сигареты. Согласно словарю Даля, эти сигареты были привезены из Испании и изготовлялись из листьев кукурузы (Ostanin 45).

explanatory foreign
асмаловскими

As Ostanin notes (45), in 1857 in Rostov-na-Donu Vasily Asmolov founded a tobacco factory (Tabachnaya Asmolovskaya fabrika), whose cigarettes were smoked also by Nikolay II.

Как замечает Останин, в 1857 в Ростове-на-Дону основал табачную фабрику (Табачная Асмоловская фабрика), чьи сигареты курил сам Николай II (Ostanin 45).

explanatory Russia
Птоломей

According to Ptolemy, the Greek-Egyptian astronomer of the Ancient Roman Empire (2th century BC), the universe had the Earth at its center, while the Sun and the Moon, as well as all stars and planets orbited our planet (geocentric model). From the late 16th century onward, this model was gradually superseded by the heliocentric model developed by Copernicus (1473–1543), Galileo (1564–1642), and Kepler (1571–1630).

Согласно Птолемею, греко-египетскому астроному Древнеримской империи (II век до н.э.), Земля была центром Вселенной, а Солнце, Луна и другие звезды и планеты вращались вокруг нее (геоцентрическая модель). С XVI века эта модель была постепенно вытеснена гелиоцентической моделью, разработаной Коперником (1473–1543), Галилеем (1564–1642), и Кеплером (1571–1630).

foreign character
Дорофеич

Patronymic, son of Dorofei. Dorofei is a name of Greek origin, literally meaning “gift of God.” It isn’t much used in the Russian world, except for the monastic, sacred context. The Ptolemaic model (suggested by the name of this character) was adopted by the Christian church, as it suited well its model of world. Any other interpretation was persecuted (Galileo’s case is telling in this regard).

Отчество: сын Дорофея. Дорофей — имя греческого происхождения, буквально означающее “Божий дар”. Оно почти не употребляется в русскоговорящих регионах, кроме как в священном контексте (в монастырях). Модель Птолемея (на что указывает имя героя) была принята христианской церковью, так как она хорошо соответствовала церковной модели мира. Все остальные интерпретации были преследуемы и наказуемы (показательный пример — случай с Галилеем).

register/style
масон

Russian freemasonry started in the eighteenth century and spread in society especially among the intelligentsia in the 18th-19th centuries. See also: D. Smith, Working the Rough Stone: Freemasonry and Society in Eighteenth-Century Russia *(Northern Illinois UP, 1999); A. Serkov, *Russkoe masonstvo. 1731-2000 (ROSSPEN, 2001); R. Faggionato, A Rosicrucian Utopia in Eighteenth-Century Russia. The Masonic Circle of N.I. Novikov (Springer, 2005).

Русское масонство зародилось в XVIII веке и приобрело известность в обществе, в частности, среди интеллигенции, в XVIII-XIX веках. См. также: D. Smith, “Working the Rough Stone: Freemasonry and Society in Eighteenth-Century Russia” (Northern Illinois UP, 1999); A. Serkov, “Russkoe masonstvo. 1731-2000” (ROSSPEN, 2001); R. Faggionato, “A Rosicrucian Utopia in Eighteenth-Century Russia. The Masonic Circle of N.I. Novikov” (Springer, 2005).

explanatory Russia
сказывают

Dated, poetic: to say.

Устаревшее, поэтическое: говорить.

register/style
фигурацiя

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme “i” was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: фигурация). The term is ironic, as it suggests he is not the least important person (figure) in the lodge. Ilya mistakenly uses the word “фигурант” in chapter 4 (R178/E51).

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема “i” была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы “фигурация”). Слово употреблено с иронией, указывая на то, что он в ложе не последний по важности человек. Илья ошибочно использует слово “фигурант” в главе 4 (R178/E51).

archaism
значительных у нас лиц,

The expression “znachitel’noe litso” (prominent personage) is generally linked with Nikolai Gogol’s povest’ The Overcoat. This character is an unnamed bureaucrat who holds power as a general supervisor. Akaky (the main character of the povest’) seeks help from him to no avail. This entire section of the novel may be read as a parody of Gogol’s style. Read The Overcoat in the original here and a translation here. Sokolov on Gogol: “he always was and still is, for me, the number-one writer. At the age of six or seven, my mother and I spent several months in Ukraine visiting ‘Gogol’’s Places.’ She, too, was in love with Gogol” (Vaiman, “A Conversation” 367).

Выражение “значительное лицо” обычно ассоциируется с повестью Н. Гоголя “Шинель”. Этот герой — безымянный бюрократ в позиции власти, начальник над подчиненными. Акакий (главный герой повести) ищет у него помощи, но безрезультатно. Эту часть романа в целом можно рассматривать как пародию на гоголевский стиль. Прочитать “Шинель” в оригинале можно здесь, а в английском переводе — здесь. Соколов о Гоголе: “Он всегда был и остается для меня писателем номер один. Тем более что в шесть или семь лет я с матерью провел несколько месяцев в гоголевских местах на Украине. Она была тоже влюблена в Гоголя” (Vaiman, “A Conversation” 367).

intertextuality self-reference
журфиксы

From the French “jour fixe.” A certain day of the week designated for the regular reception of guests in a family house in pre-revolutionary Russia.

С французского “jour fixe”. Специально отведенный день недели для регулярной встречи гостей у себя дома в дореволюционной России.

A show held in honour of some of its participants.

Спектакль либо другое представление в честь или в пользу одного из его участников

шибче

Faster (this adjective is used in Ukrainian; for Russian language it signals a colloquial register).

Быстрее (прилагательное употребляется в украинском языке; в русском языке относится к разговорной речи).

register/style foreign
прошпектов

Dated orthography: today it would be проспект. Ostanin (45) notes that in 1897 the Pogarskaya sigaretno-sigarnaya fabrika produced a kind of pipe tobacco called “Nevsky proshpekt.”

Устаревшая орфография: сегодня правильное написание слова было бы “проспект”. Останин замечает, что в 1897 на Погарской сигаретно-сигарной фабрике выпускался трубочный табак “Невский прошпект” (Ostanin 45).

phraseologism
громаднаго

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго.

register/style
городоваго

A lower rank in the city police (in the Russian state from 1862 to 1917). Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго. Here the word is used as an adjectival noun.

Низший чин городской полиции (в Российском государстве 1862-1917 гг.). Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание адъективного существительного должно было бы быть -eго.

archaism
миллiонных

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme “i” was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: миллионных).

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема “i” была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы “миллионных”).

register/style
Болтали о новых часах Буре и об африканских бурах

Alliteration (b); pun; Amf3GD+Amf3M.

Аллитерация (б), игра слов. Амф3ГД + Амф3М.

sound metrical pattern pun
часах Буре

The Pavel Bure (Paul Buhre) watch company was established in 1874 (although the family had started this activity back in 1815). In 1899 Pavel Bure was given the title of “court supplier to the Emperor” (between 1887 and 1917 the Russian court bought more than 10,000 watches from his factory). Bure watches are mentioned in many literary works, for example by Anton Chekhov, or Il’f and Petrov in their The Golden Calf. After the 1917 Revolution the Bure factory stopped its activity in Russia, but continued to work in Switzerland.

Часовая компания Павел Буре (Paul Buhre) была основана в 1874 году (хотя семья Буре занималась часовым делом с 1815 года). В 1899 году Павел Буре был удостоен титула “Поставщика Двора Его Императорского Величества” (между 1887 и 1917 годом царский двор приобрел более 10,000 часов его производства). Часы Буре упоминаются во многих литературных произведениях, например, Чехова или Ильфа и Петрова в “Золотом теленке”. После революции 1917 года часовая компания Буре прекратила свою деятельность в России, однако продолжила работу в Швейцарии.

explanatory Russia
африканских бурах

A pun played on the words Bure/Buhre and Boers (South Africans of Dutch, German, or Huguenot descent). Today their descendants are usually referred to as Afrikaans.

Игра слов: Буре (фамилия основателя часовой компании) и буры (потомки голландских, немецких и французских колонистов (гугенотов) в Южной Африке). Сегодня, потомков колонистов называют африканерами.

explanatory pun foreign
не судите да не судимы будете

Biblical set expression (Matthew 7:1; Luke 6:37).

Библейское устойчивое выражение (Матфея 7:1, Луки 6:31).

phraseologism bible intertextuality religion
воспомнили

Dated: remembered.

register/style
швейцарскаго

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго. It could be an allusion to a robbing by two Russians of a Montreux bank in 1907. One of the two was a Tolstoy fan. Montreux is an iconic city in the Russian literary cosmos because of Nabokov. Sokolov affirms “having read about these bank and train robberies in some old newspapers” (personal communication, June 27 2023). Railroad theme.

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ого. Возможно, имеется в виду ограбление банка Монтре двумя русскими в 1907 году. Один из грабителей был поклонником Толстого, а Монтре стал символическим городом в литературных кругах благодаря Набокову. Соколов утверждает, что “про ограбления банков и поезда прочел в старых газетах” (личная переписка, 27 июня 2023). Тема железной дороги.

register/style explanatory theme foreign
ограбленiи

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme “i” was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: ограблении).

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема “i” была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы “ограблении”).

register/style
ограбленiи колорадскаго поезда

A possible allusion to “The Great Train Robbery,” a 1903 American silent film by Edwin S. Porter, or to the Cotopaxi train robbery occurred on the evening of August 31, 1891 at a time when robbing trains carrying railroad and federal property was not a rare event in the United States. Sokolov affirms “having read about these bank and train robberies in some old newspapers” (personal communication, June 27 2023). Railroad theme.

Возможная отсылка к “Большому ограблению поезда”, американскому немому фильму Эдвина С. Портера, выпущенному в 1903 году, или знаметитому ограблению поезда в Котопакси, случившемуся вечером 31 августа 1981 года, когда грабление поездов, перевозящих рельсы и федеральную собственность, было нередким явлением в Соединенных Штатах. Тема железной дороги.

Ксенофонт

His name evokes that of Xenophon of Athens (5th-4th century BC), military leader, philosopher (disciple of Socrates), and historian, thanks to whose many detailed works we know much about his times.

Его имя происходит от Ксенофонта Афинского (V-VI вв. до н.э.), полководец, философ (ученик Сократа), историк, благодаря чьим подробным работам многое известно про его временной период.

Отчество: сын Ардальона. Происхождение имени может быть связано с латинским словом “ardalio”, то есть, суетливый человек.

башибузуки

A soldier of the Turkish irregular army in the 18th and 19th century. More generally, a rude, unbridled violent man.

Солдат турецких иррегулярных войск в XVIII-XIX вв. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
базук

Of the apparent anachronism of this term Sokolov says: “I always thought that in the ancient times a certain cannon was called bazooka, and that the modern anti-tank weapon was named after it. I couldn’t find any confirmation of this idea on the Internet. But I still like to think I’m right. And if I’m not, there’s nothing I can do about it” (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

О видимом анахронизме данного термина Соколов говорит следующее: “Мне всегда казалось, что базукой называлась в старину некая пушка, а современное противотанковое ружье названо в ее честь. Подтверждение этой идее в интернете я не нашел. Но мне все равно хочется думать, что я прав. А если нет, то ничего не поделаешь” (личная переписка, 25 августа 2023).

Диалектическое: прочий.

explanatory
Балаклавой

The Battle of Balaclava was fought on 25 October, 1854 during the Crimean War (1853-1856) against the alliance formed by the British, France and the Ottoman Empires. To the Russians it was a victory and boosted in morale. Sokolov notes that Kuprin lived in Balaclava (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 130). Ilya also mentions the city later (R248/E172).

Балаклавское сражение произошло 25 октября 1854 года во время Крымской войны (1853-1856). Битва завершилась победой русских и способствовала поддержанию духа русской армии. Соколов отмечает, что Куприн жил в Балаклаве (“Bol’shoe pis’mo” 130). Илья позже вновь упоминает этот город (R248/E172).

language
Эрлиха

According to Ostanin (46), Natan Erlikh (Nathan Ehrlich) was —at the beginning of the Twentieth century— the head of a French industrial group producing shoes.

Согласно Останину, Натан Эрлих — в начале XX века глава французской промышленной группы, производившей обувь.

explanatory foreign
штиблет

Men’s shoes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Мужские туфли. Изображено ниже:

Мотив обуви.

Фрак, пальто. От французского “surtout”. Изображено ниже:

foreign motif
Никодим

Nicodemus is a Biblical name. According to the Gospel of John, he is described as a learned doctor of the Law, a Pharisee, a member of the Sanhedrin, and one of Jesus’ disciples. An apocryphal Gospel is attributed to him by tradition.

character bible religion intertextuality
Ермолаич

Patronymic, son of Ermolai. Ermolai is a name of Greek origin, meaning approximately “people of Hermes,” herald of the gods and god of commerce.

character foreign
околоточным

A local police officer in Imperial Russia.

Устаревшее: участковый полицеский в Российской империи.

explanatory Russia
iерихонская труба

Set expression: extremely loud, deafening. The expression derives from the Bible: according to Joshua 6:1–27, the walls of Jericho fell after the Israelites marched around the city walls once a day for six days and seven times on the seventh day then blew their trumpets. “Jericho trumpets” are also called the sirens that during World War II were installed on the German airplanes Junkers Ju87 with the purpose of intimidating.

Устойчивое выражение: очень громко, оглушительно. Выражение берет начало в Библии: согласно книге Иисуса Навина 6:1-27, стены Иерихона рухнули после того, как израильтяне затрубили в трубы, предварительно обходя город единожды в течение шести дней и семикратно на седьмой день. “Иерихонскими трубами” также назывались сирены, установленные во Вторую мировую войну на немецкий бомбардировщик “Юнкерс-87” с целью запугивания.

register/style
Варфоломеич

Patronymic, son of Barfolomei. According to some interpretation, the Aramaic name Bartholomew could be a Hebrew version of Ptolemy. So this Ignaty could be the son of that Ptolomey Dorofeich mentioned above.

Отчество: сын Варфоломея. Согласно некоторым интерпретациям, арамейское имя Варфоломей могло быть еврейской версией имени Птолемей, Таким образом, Игнатий мог быть сыном представленного выше Птолемея Дорофеича.

character explanatory
просвещенец

This word carries a double meaning: he is a “prosveshchenets” because he works at the typography “Prosveshchenie”, but he also is, literally, a popularizer of knowledge in doing this job.

Это слово имеет двойное значение: он “просвещенец”, потому что работает в издательстве “Просвещение”, но в силу своей работы он также является просвещенцем (просветителем) в буквальном смысле этого слова.

character foreign
Игнатiй

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme “i” was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform.

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема “i” была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года.

register/style
Варфоломеичем

Patronymic, son of Barfolomei. According to some interpretations, the Aramaic name Bartholomew could be a Hebrew version of Ptolemy. So this Ignaty could be the son of that Ptolomey Dorofeich mentioned above.

Отчество: сын Варфоломея. Согласно некоторым интерпретациям, арамейское имя Варфоломей могло быть еврейской версией имени Птолемей, Таким образом, Игнатий мог быть сыном представленного выше Птолемея Дорофеича.

character explanatory
с

Dated: the словое́рс (slovojers). An obsolete honorific suffix derived from сударь (súdarʹ, sir) previously used to emphasize one’s politeness or lower social position.

Устаревшее: словое́рс. Вышедший из употребления суффикс для выражения почтения с собеседнику, исходно образованный от слова “сударь” и использовавшийся для подчеркивания вежливости или низшей социальной позиции говорящего.

explanatory register/style language
бельвю

French “belle vue,” a beautiful view.

Французское “belle vue”: прекрасный вид.

foreign
блюститель порядка

That is, the “okolotochny,” a local police officer in Imperial Russia.

То есть, “околоточный”.

explanatory

Никодим

Nicodemus is a Biblical name. According to the Gospel of John, he is described as a learned doctor of the Law, a Pharisee, a member of the Sanhedrin, and one of Jesus’ disciples. An apocryphal Gospel is attributed to him by tradition.

Ермолаич

Patronymic, son of Ermolai. Ermolai is a name of Greek origin, meaning approximately “people of Hermes,” herald of the gods and god of commerce.

motif
Ксенофонт

His name evokes that of Xenophon of Athens (5th-4th century BC), military leader, philosopher (disciple of Socrates), and historian, thanks to whose many detailed works we know much about his times.

Его имя происходит от Ксенофонта Афинского (V-VI вв. до н.э.), полководец, философ (ученик Сократа), историк, благодаря чьим подробным работам многое известно про его временной период.

писчiй спазм

A pun played on the expressions “ptichy glaz” (bird’s eye) and “pischy spazm” (writer’s cramp).

Игра слов, построенная на выражениях “птичий глаз” и “писчий спазм”.

pun explanatory
воробьем

Sparrow. Various traditions have depicted the sparrow as a symbol for lechery, prudence, solitude, or humankind (Rowland, Birds 157–159). It is also known as a lively, chatty bird, thus perhaps explaining the simile here. Animal motif.

phraseologism

Dated: the словое́рс (slovojers). An obsolete honorific suffix derived from сударь (súdarʹ, sir) previously used to emphasize one’s politeness or lower social position.

Устаревшее: словое́рс. Вышедший из употребления суффикс для выражения почтения с собеседнику, исходно образованный от слова “сударь” и использовавшийся для подчеркивания вежливости или низшей социальной позиции говорящего.

rhyme
Паламахтеров

Ostanin (43) suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of “Palamakherov” (from the verb palit’, to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are “So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!” (“Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки”) (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию “Паломахеров” (от глагола “палить”), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: “Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки” (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).

character foreign
Якова

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Якова Ильича

Now the narration goes back to Yakov Il’ich. His unskilled cunning (his inability to lie and pretend, which was mentioned at the beginning of the chapter) is paired with that of his great-grandfather in pretending he’s having luck at play.

Повествование возвращается к Якову Ильичу. Его неумелое лукавство (отсутствие умения лгать и притворяться, которое упоминается в начале главы) соотносится с таким же неумелым притворством его прадеда, который пытается выдать свое положение в игре за удачное.

explanatory character
Ильича

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

Устойчивое выражение: повторно, не прекращаясь.

phraseologism
порывался не подавать виду, что он таков, каким, естественно, просто не мог не быть

The characters’ identities are constantly confused in the novel. Here, Yakov is and is not “who he is supposed to be” — Ilya’s son? the author of the novel?

Личности героев романа находятся в постоянном замешательстве. Здесь, Яков и является, и не является тем, “кем должен быть” — сыном Ильи? автором романа?

explanatory character
Якова

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильича

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

не к желаемому, а к нежелаемому

Квази-анаграмма.

phraseologism

The novel’s sense of time is likewise brazenly distorted. Death is meaningless as the deceased can still communicate with the living, and time moves at different speeds along the various points of the Volga. Krylobyl explains this conception of time in chapter 14 (R255/E186–187).

Восприятие времени в романа так же откровенно искажено. Смерть бессмысленна, ведь умершие все равно могут взаимодействовать с живыми, а время течет с неодинаковой скоростью в разных местах Волги. Крылобыл объясняет эту концепцию времени в главе 14 (R255/E186–187).

structure intratextuality
Яков

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильич

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
Паламахтеров

Ostanin (43) suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of “Palamakherov” (from the verb palit’, to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are “So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!” (“Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки”) (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию “Паломахеров” (от глагола “палить”), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: “Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки” (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).

intertextuality intratextuality character religion
доезжачiй

Since the narration moves back in time to the Nineteenth century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -ий. This word was previously used in Note IX and will appear again in further chapters: while used in its literal sense elsewhere (a senior dog handler, who trains hounds for the hunt), here the word occurs in an unusual context, as Yakov is described as “a time handler” or, more precisely, “a handler of his practical and merciless time.”

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ий.

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго.

Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ого.
